title: Does fiber optic internet connect to your devices wirelessly? - Quora

response.answer_text: Two different things. Wired data / communications lines comes in two formats: copper (or any electrical conductor) and fiber optics. Copper carries electrons (electricity) and fiber carries photons (light). That’s the physical connections. Once connected to a common network (almost always “Ethernet” tech today), any mixture of device types can talk to each other. Wireless uses radio frequency communications, which is a from of electro-magnetic technology (like copper based wired communications), obviously without a physical medium. On that same thought… “IR” (infra-red) remotes are more like fiber over the air, in that the signal is part of the light spectrum. Wifi uses 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz frequency ranges. Think FM radio, but well beyond the dial. The physical fiber connectors are standardized. The medium doesn’t matter much in networking… the “OSI model” helps demonstrate this concept. The physical layer is independent from the “framing” layer (layer 2)… in this case Ethernet. This means that Ethernet (Wifi is an extension of that) can talk over multiple mediums… so a computer that has a copper connection, another with fiber and another with “Wifi” can all talk to each other… they have no real understanding (awareness) that the other devices are on different physical mediums/paths. The core of the Internet is all fiber optic based. Fiber optics have 100x the capacity of copper based technology: we have a lot of room to grow/advance with fiber, not as much left with copper. For the foreseeable future, wired will always be preferred over wireless: not that wireless clearly has it’s advantages and can usually do the job well-enough. It’s simply more susceptible to interference than wired communications, generally speaking. And of the two wired formats, fiber is the least susceptible to interference from external sources - anything beyond physically damaging or kinking the fiber itself: affecting the light travelling over a very small glass tube, with cladding and other layers of protection.

No. Fiber optic internet is an alternative connection to your ISP and the internet. It is not wireless, it uses fibers that transmit data by flashing light. To connect your devices you’ll still need a modem like device called an ONT and a router. Many routers include WiFi for wireless connectivity, but you could also use an access point to add wireless connectivity to your network. The connection to your ISP, fiber optic, cable, DSL, etc. has nothing to do with how devices locally connect to your network.
